sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: In a basketball game, the probability of Player A making a free throw shot is 0.85. If Player A takes 10 free throw shots, what is the probability that they will make exactly 7 of them?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of making exactly k successful free throw shots
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (n choose k)
- n is the total number of free throw shots (10 in this case)
- k is the number of successful free throw shots (7 in this case)
- p is the probability of making a successful free throw shot (0.85 in this case)

First, we need to calculate C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 successful free throw shots out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / (5040 * 6)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / 30240
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * 0.85^7 * (1-0.85)^(10-7)
P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.85^7 * 0.15^3
P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.39135393 * 0.003375
P(X = 7) â‰ˆ 0.2014

So, the probability that Player A will make exactly 7 out of 10 free throw shots is approximately 0.2014 or 20.14%.
